Dear Ms. Darwin:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
8/26/2025. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Samantha Way, area manager at 517-243-9743.
Sincerely,

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
• (2) An agency shall complete written service plans
for each child and parent or parents, as follows:
• (b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial
removal and at least once every 90
calendar days thereafter.
One of three foster care case records reviewed was not completed within 90
calendar days as required.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
• (5) An agency shall involve the child's parent or
parents and the foster parents in the development
of service plans to enable the parent or parents
and foster parents to understand the plan for the
child and the parents' and the foster parent's role
in assisting the agency in carrying out the plan. An
agency shall give a copy to and review the parent-
agency treatment plan with the parent or parents
and foster parents. The agency must inform the
parent or parents and foster parent that the
information in the parent-agency treatment plan
2

and any other information about the child and the
child's family is confidential.
Two of three foster care case records reviewed did not show documentation that the
case plan was developed with the parent/parents and/or foster parents. PATP's
were not signed, dated or check marks checked.
CPA Rule 400.12605 Adoptive family evaluation
• (1) An agency social service worker shall
complete a written adoptive evaluation within 90
days of the family signing an adoption application
and prior to approving a family for adoption.
One of three adoption case records reviewed did not complete a written evaluation
within 90 days. The report was seven months late.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED

VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance:
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows: The CAP
submitted was in response to the 2024 renewal inspection completed on
06/10/2024 and the CAP was approved on 06/17/2024. The agency was cited for
3 violations, 1 of the violations is a repeat this year. The repeated violation
3

(400.12605 -1) indicates that additional corrective action planning is needed to
show reduction of this violation.
Chief Administrator Assessment:
Chief Administrator (CA) discussed barriers that impeded the agency this year
during the exit conference held on 8/26/2025. CA reported that the largest barrier
to ensuring contract compliance has been an ongoing pattern of turnover
throughout all levels and some resignations being abrupt. This turnover includes
direct case managers, foster care supervisors, and the program director. Each
resignation results in case management issues that directly affect the agency's
contract compliance. Continuity of care is directly affected and timeliness dictated
by policy is affected when trained staff leave the agency and the case is taken on
by a worker unfamiliar with the case. The agency has been unable to fill the open
position for foster care supervisor, and this has affected review of the agency's
previous CAP, causing non-compliance.
CA reported areas of the previous CAP that had positive impacts on the agency's
procedures included utilization of the Microsoft calendar to track due dates,
monthly trainings surrounding previous licensing violations, utilization of the
MiSACWIS checklist, and weekly supervisor and team meetings in which the Book
of Business as well as the agency's database are reviewed to provide additional
due date oversight for direct staff.
Financial Overview:
Reviewed the independent agency auditor’s report dated December 30, 2024, and
the agency annual financial report. There were no financial concerns identified.
Staff Interviews:
Staff were interviewed onsite 8/26/2025. Staff interviewed were compassionate
about working for the agency citing the assistance and support they receive from
their program director, supervisors and their co-workers. They feel the
environment is good to work in but retaining the staff is very difficult. The concerns
shared was a lack of support from upper management and the way upper
management communicates with the staff. The staff reported some suggestion for
staff morale from upper management is to provide the staff with tokens of
appreciation, certificates, and fun activities such as lunch and learn. Staff feel this
might assist in retaining staff and increase the staff morale.
Description of Agency Walk Through:
The agency has the space and equipment needed to fulfil job requirements. The
files are stored securely to prevent unauthorized access.
4

VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were three safety alerts.
Safety Alert 1:
Concern: Caregivers did not have an operable smoke detector near sleeping
spaces. Smoke detector observed beeping; Cleaning supplies are accessible to
children. Dog feces in the basement, bedroom door for the foster children is not
installed properly and windows are missing screens.
Resolution: Caseworker/Program Manager and Supervisor visited the home on
05/28/2025. The home was untidy with garbage scattered around the home. The
workers instructed Caregivers to clean up the dog feces in the basement which was
still present. Caregivers picked up all feces. Workers moved all cleaning supplies
from under the bathroom and kitchen sink and placed them temporarily in the kitchen
cabinet above the sink. Workers installed a new smoke detector next to the children's
bedroom. Caregivers report that they are moving approximately June 10. The door
has been placed against the wall and the Caregivers was advised not to use it as the
children would not be able to move it in case of a fire or emergency. The caregiver
agrees to ensure that all windows remain closed until the agency can provide kiddie
locks.
Updated on 05/29: the two foster children were placed outside of the home in safety
plan with the caregiver’s parents from 05/29 to 06/02. Over the weekend, the
caregivers were able to hang the bedroom doors on hinges and place window alarms
on the windows that did not have screens. The alarms will go off if any of the
windows are opened to alert the caregivers that there is an urgent safety matter at
risk.
Safety Alert 2:
Concern: Caregiver did not have an operable carbon monoxide detector in the
home. There is a door that is not hinged properly in the kitchen area and there is a
bedroom where the door is not hinged properly and can't be opened all the way.
Resolution: On 7/7/25, Licensing worker contacted the Caregiver and requested
proof that the carbon monoxide detector was working and that the door to the
bedroom was working properly. Caregiver agreed to send the licensing worker proof
of the working carbon monoxide detector and the door and to schedule a repair for
the door to the laundry room with the loose hinges. Caregiver sent two videos on
7/9/25 that showed the batteries had been replaced in carbon monoxide detector
and it was working properly and the other showed that the bedroom door could be
opened and closed. Once the laundry room door has been repaired, the agency will
obtain proof. Caregiver provided the agency with a video verifying the bedroom door
5

opening and closing and the carbon monoxide detector working. Videos are not able
to be included in the alert.
Safety Alert 3:
Concern: Caregiver had no operable smoke detector on each level of occupancy.
One of the bedrooms was not viewed due to the caregiver indicating it was her
bedroom and the door was locked. The safety of the room could not be assessed.
Resolution: On June 13, 2025, Program Director arrived at the Caregiver’s home and
completed a walkthrough of the entire home. The basement was viewed which
contained storage items and no safety concerns. Program Manager provided a new
smoke detector near the stairs and laundry room in the basement.
The door through the children’s bedroom which was locked was opened and viewed.
It contained storage items and clothes and a twin bed underneath the items. No one
sleeps in this room. The family was able to pick the lock as they had lost the key. No
safety hazards were observed. The children's bedrooms were both appropriate. The
dual smoke detector/carbon monoxide detector between the bedrooms was tested
and working. Additional another smoke detector was provided to place above the
entryway to the kitchen. The top floor of the home is the primary bedroom and has
another living and eating area. A new smoke detector was placed and tested above
the walkway into the primary bedroom. No safety hazards were observed.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
